toc_entry.title: The Return Of the Urban Cowboy
toc_entry.description: Five years ago, Hollywood took some cowboys and cowgirls and portrayed their lives as filled with romance, heartbreak, and country music. Since then, they’ve returned to reality. And their lives have been filled with romance, heartbreak, and country music.

toc_entry.title: The Hustlers
toc_entry.description: The genteel practice of law is dead. Nowadays lawyers fight for clients, raid each other’s firms, and bill, bill, bill.

toc_entry.title: We Wanted A Test Tube Baby
toc_entry.description: The odds for having a child of our own were slim to none. We took a chance on slim.

toc_entry.title: Preacher’s Kids
toc_entry.description: My father had to have an answer for everything-adultery, spiritual crises, the pigeons defecating in the church gutter. No wonder I didn’t become a preacher. The miracle is that my sister did.

toc_entry.title: Sad Ballad Of A Mad Filly In Love With Bad Billy
toc_entry.subtitle: Western Art

toc_entry.title: The Petroleum Club
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: People who have watched a certain prime-time soap opera think they know what goes on at the Petroleum Club. They don’t.

toc_entry.title: Queen For A Day
toc_entry.description: Here they are—the Texas homecoming queens. Take a look at the girls the boys like best.

toc_entry.title: The Art-By-The-Truckload School
toc_entry.description: They’re cheesy, they’re tasteless. But each black velvet painting is a one-of-a-kind work of art.

toc_entry.title: The Neo Black Velvetists
toc_entry.description: A new chapter in art history? Five artists dabble in a medium you’ll never see at the Met.

toc_entry.title: Have I Got A Collection For You
toc_entry.subtitle: Art
toc_entry.description: With one bold acquisition the Dallas Museum of Art could double the value of its holdings. But there were a few strings attached.

toc_entry.title: Eat And Run
toc_entry.subtitle: Food
toc_entry.description: Graze on the street corners of Texas for fast, tasty, and inexpensive meals.

toc_entry.title: Missing the Pointe
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: White Nights is too much cold war, not enough Baryshnikov; After Hours is overwrought Scorcese; Mishima is a mishmash.

toc_entry.title: Dense As A Clootie Dumpling
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: It had to happen. Novelist James Michener has finally trained his macroscope on Texas, and the result is, well, long.

toc_entry.title: Is It Live Or Is It A Cd?
toc_entry.subtitle: Classical Music
toc_entry.description: Compact discs: coasters? Frisbees? or the best sound you’ll ever hear?

toc_entry.title: Behind the Lines
toc_entry.description: Winners of Dallas, at ease!

toc_entry.title: Back Roads
toc_entry.description: They said it couldn’t be done, but Larry Brumfield built Texas’ largest indoor bass aquarium.

toc_entry.title: Post-Modern Times
toc_entry.description: NorthPark Mall inaugurated an epoch twenty years ago. It’s still the standard for upscale shopping.

toc_entry.title: Downtown
toc_entry.description: You have to wonder if guys like San Antonio’s C. A. Stubbs aren’t the future of urban politics.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective statewide guide to entertainment and events.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: A turf battle over shrimp on the coast; a nominee for the meanest man in Houston; a former Cowboy’s reflections on why athletes go broke.

toc_entry.title: Touts
toc_entry.description: The sincerest form of plattery: imaginative new serving pieces for the holiday season.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: Fundamentalists lose ground in textbook war; White maneuvers to keep Hispanic support; round two for Crystal City.
